The following is a time series analysis question on the topic of moving averages:

The monthly sales data for a software company over the last 12 months is given in the table below. Compute a 3-month moving average for the sales data and indicate the sales trend.

Month | Sales ($1000s)
---|---
1 | 40
2 | 45
3 | 50
4 | 47
5 | 42
6 | 44
7 | 50
8 | 48
9 | 52
10 | 55
11 | 58
12 | 60
message_2:
To compute a 3-month moving average, we will average the sales data for every 3 consecutive months. We can start from month 3 and go up to month 12. Here are the calculations:

3-month moving average for months 1-3: (40 + 45 + 50) / 3 = 135 / 3 = 45
3-month moving average for months 2-4: (45 + 50 + 47) / 3 = 142 / 3 ≈ 47.33
3-month moving average for months 3-5: (50 + 47 + 42) / 3 = 139 / 3 ≈ 46.33
3-month moving average for months 4-6: (47 + 42 + 44) / 3 = 133 / 3 ≈ 44.33
3-month moving average for months 5-7: (42 + 44 + 50) / 3 = 136 / 3 ≈ 45.33
3-month moving average for months 6-8: (44 + 50 + 48) / 3 = 142 / 3 ≈ 47.33
3-month moving average for months 7-9: (50 + 48 + 52) / 3 = 150 / 3 = 50
3-month moving average for months 8-10: (48 + 52 + 55) / 3 = 155 / 3 ≈ 51.67
3-month moving average for months 9-11: (52 + 55 + 58) / 3 = 165 / 3 = 55
3-month moving average for months 10-12: (55 + 58 + 60) / 3 = 173 / 3 ≈ 57.67

Now, let's analyze the sales trend based on the moving averages:

The moving averages show an overall increasing trend in sales. The sales start at a lower moving average of 45 and gradually increase to a moving average of 57.67 by the end of the 12-month period. There are some fluctuations in the middle, but the general trend is upward.
